In this scenario, only the driver's own property (the wing mirror) was damaged, and no other party was involved. Therefore, the driver is not legally obligated to stop. Option A is incorrect as there's no requirement to report this to the police. Option C is not necessary as leaving a note on a hedge is not a legal requirement in this case. Option D is also incorrect as there's no obligation to report hedge damage to the local council in this situation.

documentation.title: GDPR compliance in ads SDK for iOS/Android
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have opened [this question in SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58644088/gdpr-compliance-in-ads-sdk-for-ios-android), but was suggested to ask here, as the solution might come from a lawyer, rather than developer. 

I work on a native ads SDK for iOS/Android (banner, interstitial, video ads etc.).  

We want to comply with GDPR regulations (and others, like COPPA, later).

So I have few questions here: 

1. Should the SDK provide a way (set of get/set functions) for publisher to read/write the GDPR data? I talk here about the values of `IABConsent_SubjectToGDPR`, `IABConsent_ConsentString`, `IABConsent_ParsedPurposeConsents` and `IABConsent_ParsedVendorConsents` in user defaults or shared preferences...
2. If yes then should the SDK parse the `IABConsent_ConsentString` and store the parsed data to `IABConsent_ParsedPurposeConsents` and `IABConsent_ParsedVendorConsents`?
3. Or, maybe the SDK should ask the user by itself for the consent data?
4. Even if none of the above has to be implemented in the SDK, it still has to read the GDPR related data from `NSUserDefaults`/`SharedPreferences`. So should it read the `IABConsent_ConsentString` and parse it by itself? Or can I just rely on the parsed values (`IABConsent_ParsedPurposeConsents` and `IABConsent_ParsedVendorConsents`)?
5. And, in general, who is responsible to collect this data from the user, build consent string and parse it to vendors and purposes lists? Is it the publisher (app developer) or each one who touches this data (e.g. SDKs in use)?

Thank you.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Generally if an app is using a third party add service, the app handles the GDPR rules. 

That could change with future court rulings, but ,for now, the app should tell the user what info is being shared with the third party advertisers and let the users consent.

> Additionally, if you are using a 3rd\-party to show ads (aka using an ad network/exchange), it's possible you'll need to mention all those involved (the ad server, exchange, DMPs, DSPs, etc), which makes getting consent for programmatic ads infeasible. That said, it may be that a broader statement of "we'll be sharing with various advertising partners" would be enough. [https://adzerk.com/blog/gdpr\-ad\-tech/](https://adzerk.com/blog/gdpr-ad-tech/)

The app may use other ad networks in addition to the one you work for, so it is best left up to the app so you don't force the user to go through multiple GDPR notices.

38.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: As the developer of an ads SDK for iOS/Android, which approach is most appropriate for GDPR compliance according to current interpretations?

A) The SDK should directly ask users for consent and handle all GDPR-related data collection and processing internally.

B) The SDK should provide functions for app developers to read/write GDPR data, but leave the responsibility of collecting consent to the app developers.

C) The SDK should automatically parse and store all GDPR-related data without involving the app developers or users.

D) The SDK should ignore GDPR compliance entirely, as it's solely the responsibility of the app using the SDK.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the information provided, the current interpretation is that the app using third-party ad services (like SDKs) is generally responsible for handling GDPR rules. The SDK should provide functionality for app developers to manage GDPR data, but the actual collection of consent and informing users about data sharing should be done by the app. This allows for a more comprehensive approach, especially if the app uses multiple ad networks. The SDK providing functions for reading/writing GDPR data (option B) aligns with this interpretation, allowing app developers to manage consent while giving the SDK access to necessary information for compliance.

documentation.title: Do I have the right to get a copy of the source code I wrote during an internship? (Germany)
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I did an internship in a small software company in Germany and wrote mainly two programs, one which is just an example to learn the language which has no monetary value and another one which could be sold by the company if they finish a few remaining parts.

Now the internship is over and I asked my boss for a copy of the source code I personally wrote myself so that I can look up what I learned and have an example for this programming language. 

I have no intent to republish the code in any way, including making it open source or selling the code itself or a product made from it. It's just the first stuff I wrote in this language and I would like to keep it as template and example.

He declined my request and said that they never give away their source code.

A quick online research taught me that if a program was written at the employer's disposition, they have the exclusive and full market rights. In my opinion, this sounds like they have the power to decide what I may do with it (e.g. prohibit selling or publishing), but it does not really say anything about the right to own a copy for personal educational purposes. 

Other sources also said that the author always holds the inalienable (except through descent) copyright, so I as non\-lawyer would interpret this in a way that grants me at least the right to own a copy, even if I may not republish it in any way.

My internship contract did not say anything about ownership and usage rights of the code I write.

I'm not going to fight for this, but I'm interested in my theoretical rights as employed (or internship) programmer. Do I have the right to obtain a copy of all source codes I purely wrote myself? What rules are there concerning this situation?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Germany may be different, however in the United States this would be considered [work\-for\-hire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_for_hire) and the employer would be the rightful owner of the source code.

---

*Regardless of jurisdiction, and from a more practical point of view, you are better off **not** having a copy of the source code. Using it as reference or example in the future could easily turn into (unintentional) copyright infringement. If, in the future, you write code you would like to be able to freely keep and reuse in any project, make sure the owner/employer licenses it using something like the [BSD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BSD_licenses), [MIT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_License), or [ISC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISC_license) license.*

39.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In the context of software development internships and code ownership, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) An intern always retains full copyright and ownership of any code they write during their internship, regardless of the employer's policies.

B) If an internship contract doesn't explicitly mention code ownership, the intern has the right to keep and use copies of all code they wrote for any purpose.

C) Work created during an internship is typically considered "work-for-hire" and the employer generally owns the rights to the code, even if it's not explicitly stated in the contract.

D) Interns have an inalienable right to keep copies of code they wrote for personal educational purposes, as long as they don't republish or sell it.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. In most jurisdictions, including the United States (and likely similar in Germany), work created during employment or internship is typically considered "work-for-hire." This means the employer owns the rights to the code, even if not explicitly stated in the contract. While interns may desire to keep copies for educational purposes, they don't have an automatic right to do so. The employer has the authority to restrict access to the code they own. Option A is incorrect because interns don't retain full copyright in work-for-hire situations. Option B is false because lack of explicit mention in the contract doesn't grant rights to the intern. Option D, while perhaps desirable for interns, is not a legal right in most cases. It's advisable for interns to seek permission or clarify code ownership policies before assuming they can keep copies of their work.

documentation.title: Why are private game servers illegal?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Over on Arqade we were discussing a question which was asking about private servers for a game called World of Warcraft. The discussion was about if using and/or hosting a private server is illegal not just against the TOS.

If it is illegal what laws is it breaking?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Ok, so it looks like there really are many questions being asked.

1\) Is it illegal to host / own / operate a private server for games that require a server of such? And why?

2\) Is it illegal to host / own / operate a private server for WOW? And why?

3\) Is it illegal to join a private server for games that require a server? and why?

4\) Is it illegal to join a private server for WOW?

**Answers**

1 \& 2\) This depends on the game that is being hosted. There are many games that require servers in which this is not only legal, but encouraged by the company. MineCraft is one that comes to mind. You can host MineCraft servers, and even modify the server code. You can even charge for this service. However,for games like WOW, In short, yes if the server is profiting or If the server is running stolen or leaked software or If the server is distributing client files.

If the server was recreated from the developers own mind, and was only compatible with the WOW server, then it's a bit more gray and depends on the Judge's level of understanding of technology.

3 \& 4\) This comes down to the EULA. If the EULA is like MineCraft, then you are good to go. If the EULA is like WOW, which forbids both modification of the client **and** participation on emulated servers then it is a violation of EULA. If WOW did not have the second part of "participation on emulated servers", then a user could modify on the router level to point to a private server.

40.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A group of friends decides to set up a private server for World of Warcraft (WoW). Which of the following scenarios is most likely to be considered legal?

A) They recreate the server code from scratch, don't distribute any official WoW client files, and don't charge players to access the server.
B) They use leaked WoW server software but don't charge players to access the server.
C) They create their own server code and charge players a small fee to cover server costs.
D) They set up the server using official WoW software and allow free access to anyone who wants to join.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
Option A is the most likely to be considered legal because it avoids the main issues that make private servers illegal. By recreating the server code from scratch, they're not using stolen or leaked software. Not distributing client files and not charging players helps avoid copyright infringement and profiting from Blizzard's intellectual property.

Option B is illegal because it uses leaked software, which is a form of copyright infringement.

Option C, while using original code, becomes problematic by charging fees. This could be seen as profiting from Blizzard's intellectual property (the game concept and compatibility with WoW clients).

Option D is clearly illegal as it uses official WoW software without authorization, which is a direct violation of copyright laws and Blizzard's terms of service.

It's important to note that even option A exists in a legal gray area. While it's the least likely to be illegal, it could still potentially face legal challenges depending on how closely it mimics WoW and how it's interpreted by the courts.

documentation.title: Information about Indian court cases available online
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Based on my experience searching for information about Indian court cases online, the only information that is available online for a case is the Court Judgment. This is the document authored by a judge (or judges) giving their decision on a case.

However, this information is by definition incomplete. I would like as complete a description of the case as possible, in particular including the submissions from the plaintiff/petitioner, as well as responses etc. The judgment by itself just includes whatever the judges feel like mentioning from the case documentation, and it's wholly inadequate as documentation of a case. If the other information is not recorded in an accessible form, that would be most unfortunate.

So, I was wondering whether this information was available online, possibly as a paid service. If not, why not? While this seems like a obvious and simple question, I've not found any clear statement of this anywhere. However, given that I have failed to find it so far, it at least seems that this information, even if available somewhere, is not very accessible.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The judgement is the definitive record
--------------------------------------

The [*Destruction of Records Act*](https://legislative.gov.in/sites/default/files/A1917-05.pdf) 1917 allow the high court to set [rules](https://highcourtchd.gov.in/sub_pages/left_menu/Rules_orders/high_court_rules/Vol-V--PDF/chap5partCV5.pdf) on what records are to be kept and for how long. In summary, a very small number, including the judgement are kept indefinitely and the remainder are split into Part A (important stuff) and Part B (less important stuff) and kept for 30 and 6 years respectively.

There is no obligation for these to be publicly available so, generally, they aren’t. They are usually publicly *accessible* by going to the register of the relevant court and asking to see them which may involve payment of an administrative fee. Some records are, however, classified or confidential depending on the nature of the case (e.g. national security, cases involving children etc.)

Once a case is completed and all avenues of review have been exhausted, the submissions and evidence are of no value. Only the fact of the case and the reasons in the judgement matter.

41.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to the Destruction of Records Act 1917 and related rules in India, which of the following statements is correct regarding court case records?

A) All court documents, including submissions and evidence, are kept indefinitely and are easily accessible online.

B) Only judgments are kept indefinitely, while other documents are divided into Part A (kept for 30 years) and Part B (kept for 6 years).

C) All court documents are classified as confidential and are not accessible to the public under any circumstances.

D) Judgments and all supporting documents are kept for a uniform period of 50 years before being destroyed.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The Destruction of Records Act 1917 allows high courts to set rules for record keeping. According to these rules, only judgments are kept indefinitely. Other documents are divided into Part A (important documents kept for 30 years) and Part B (less important documents kept for 6 years). While these documents are not typically available online, they may be accessible by visiting the court registry and paying an administrative fee, unless classified or confidential. The judgment is considered the definitive record of the case once all appeals are exhausted.

documentation.title: If Van Gogh is in Public Domain, why there are restrictions in the Van Gogh museum?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've been to the **Van Gogh museum** in Amsterdam, and I was a little disappointed because there were no pictures of some of his most famous work \- "The Starry Night" and "Starry Night Over the Rhône".

Well, it is well known that Van Gogh artwork is in public domain, according to this [question](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/38276/is-van-goghs-starry-night-in-the-public-domain).

And I also know that these artworks are in the MoMA (New York City) and in the Musée D'Orsay (Paris). But why can't the museum use a replica? Or sell derived artwork in the museum shop? Or in the art books sold there? Or even tell us about these paintings during the history and life of Van Gogh presented in the museum? 

It was like these paintings never existed!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There isn’t a legal restriction
-------------------------------

Which is to say they could show replica’s if they wanted to; they just don’t want to. This is fairly typical \- art museums display art, not reproductions of art. They also tend to be interested in displaying the art they have, not telling the life story of the artist.

42.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which of the following statements best explains why the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam does not display replicas of famous Van Gogh paintings like "The Starry Night" that are housed in other museums?

A) It is illegal to display replicas of public domain artwork in museums.
B) The museum is legally restricted from showing artworks not in their physical collection.
C) There is a copyright agreement between museums preventing the display of replicas.
D) The museum chooses not to display replicas as a matter of curatorial policy.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. According to the information provided, there is no legal restriction preventing the Van Gogh Museum from displaying replicas of famous paintings housed elsewhere. The museum's decision not to show replicas is a matter of curatorial policy, as art museums typically prefer to display original artworks rather than reproductions. This choice reflects common practices in the art world, where museums focus on exhibiting their own collections rather than providing comprehensive coverage of an artist's entire body of work through replicas. Options A, B, and C are incorrect because they suggest legal or contractual restrictions that do not actually exist in this scenario.

documentation.title: Is it always a good idea to instruct opposing lawyers to speak directly?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: It is a common practice that opposing parties communicate via their lawyers rather than the parties communicating directly to each other.

Besides saving the parties' time, what are the benefits and what are the drawbacks associated with this practice?

Does it happen that the opposing parties would be unable to come to a settlement directly, but would be able to have that conversation between lawyers?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Just using an objective intermediary can produce settlements that parties can't reach in direct confrontation. That's why *mediation* is a popular tool for resolving conflicts.

Using lawyers as mediators has some added benefits:

1. Lawyers know the law and rules of litigation better than laymen and so they can tell their clients what the range of possible outcomes are, and when communicating with opposing counsel they both know what is realistic.
2. Lawyers are (at least in principle) [forbidden to lie in the course of their professional conduct](https://professionalliabilitymatters.com/legal-malpractice/lying-during-settlement-negotiations/).

I.e., using lawyers should reduce the amount of gaming involved in resolving a conflict.

**And if that's not reason enough to get opposing lawyers speaking directly:** [Rules of litigation ***require*** opposing counsel to "meet and confer"](https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/meet_and_confer) regarding many procedural issues.

A typical example is [CCP §2023\.010](https://codes.findlaw.com/ca/code-of-civil-procedure/ccp-sect-2023-010/) which requires the court to sanction a party for "*Failing to confer in person, by telephone, or by letter with an opposing party or attorney in a reasonable and good faith attempt to resolve informally any dispute concerning discovery.*"

The judicial system thinks it's *always* a good idea for opposing lawyers to speak directly because it can only reduce the burden on the public courts. Lawyers are officers of the courts to which they have been admitted to practice, and so while their primary duty is to their clients, they also have an obligation to uphold the law and avoid misusing the courts. [Here's an essay published by the ABA](https://www.americanbar.org/groups/litigation/committees/pretrial-practice-discovery/practice/2017/tips-on-meet-and-confer-conferences/) that further explains, "cooperation represents the shortest, fastest, and least costly path to what the rules, as applied, ultimately would require the parties to do anyway."

From the perspective of the client, the only drawback to conference that I can think of is the theoretical risk that one lawyer will unnecessarily divulge some piece of information that the other party can exploit to its advantage. Such a mistake would be grounds for a malpractice claim against the lawyer who committed it. And if it is brought to the attention of a court overseeing the process then the court may take steps to mitigate the damage to the party so disadvantaged. A common example is in criminal law where a judge will prohibit improper statements or evidence from being exposed to the jury.

43.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In the context of legal proceedings, what is the primary reason why courts often require opposing counsel to "meet and confer"?

A) To increase billable hours for attorneys
B) To reduce the burden on public courts
C) To ensure clients are present for all discussions
D) To prolong the litigation process

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B) To reduce the burden on public courts. The documentation explicitly states that "The judicial system thinks it's always a good idea for opposing lawyers to speak directly because it can only reduce the burden on the public courts." This practice is designed to resolve issues informally and efficiently without unnecessarily involving the court system.

Answer A is incorrect because increasing billable hours is not a goal of the judicial system. 

Answer C is incorrect because the "meet and confer" requirement is specifically for attorneys, not clients.

Answer D is incorrect because the goal is to expedite the process, not prolong it. The documentation mentions that "cooperation represents the shortest, fastest, and least costly path" to resolution.

documentation.title: If I share work (created in my own time) with my employer, do they own it?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Last weekend I started to put together a visual guide about a software development process.

It's something I have developed over 10 years based on my experience, and I believe it would do very well if published into a book. Something I have always wanted to do.

I have created it in my own time, and my current employer would benefit hugely from this guide, even though it's still a basic draft.

If I share it with my employer I am concerned they will wrongly assume they own it and present it as their own. If I then publish into a book they might think they can sue me, and I would have nothing to prove the work belongs to myself.

Is there a way to share this with my employer, and still be able to publish it myself without issues?

(In the UK)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is there a way to share this with my employer, and still be able to publish it myself without issues?

Publish it on your website/blog *first*. Then give your employer the link.

If your employment responsibilities do not include creating stuff like that, or it was (substantially) created before your employment started, it is yours.

44.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: An employee in the UK has created a visual guide about a software development process in their own time, based on 10 years of experience. They want to share it with their employer but also publish it as a book in the future. What is the best course of action to protect their intellectual property rights?

A) Keep the guide completely secret from the employer to avoid any potential claims of ownership
B) Share the guide with the employer without taking any precautions
C) Publish the guide on a personal website or blog first, then share the link with the employer
D) Formally register the copyright for the guide before sharing it with anyone

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Publishing the guide on a personal website or blog first, then sharing the link with the employer is the best course of action. This establishes a clear record of the employee's ownership and creation of the work prior to sharing it with the employer. It provides a timestamped public record that can be used as evidence if any disputes arise later. Additionally, this approach allows the employee to share the valuable information with their employer while maintaining their rights to publish it as a book in the future. 

Option A is overly cautious and prevents potential benefits to both the employee and employer. Option B risks the employer incorrectly assuming ownership without any protection for the employee. Option D, while providing some protection, is not necessary in this case and may be time-consuming and costly compared to simply publishing online first.

documentation.title: Does the federal government have authority to impose tax laws at the state level?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I was reading [IRS Stops Attempt To Bypass Trump Tax Law, MD Lawsuit Continues](https://patch.com/maryland/annapolis/irs-stops-attempt-bypass-trump-tax-law-md-lawsuit-continues). The article states:

> ... The IRS said Tuesday that states cannot bypass a $10,000 cap on
>  state and local tax (SALT) deductions imposed by the Republican tax
>  law of 2017\. That hurts taxpayers in high property tax states like
>  Maryland.
> 
> 
> The IRS effectively nullified legislation in New Jersey and several
>  other states that allowed municipalities to establish charitable funds
>  where taxpayers can donate in return for a property tax credit. The
>  legislation was intended to protect taxpayers from a potential
>  increase in the federal income tax as a result of the Trump
>  Administration's cap on the state and local tax deduction (SALT).

The article is brief, and seems to lack the exact details how how the federal government is achieving its goals. Or maybe it is there and I don't see it (fiat?).

In any case, I thought states are allowed to determine their own criteria for tax credits. It seems like the federal government is imposing tax law at the state level.

Does the federal government have authority to impose tax laws at the state level?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: They aren't "imposing tax laws at the state level", and the states are still perfectly free to award whatever credits they like. There's a more complete explanation [here](https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2019/06/11/us/ap-us-tax-workarounds.html?searchResultPosition=30). 

Before 2017, if you paid, say, $30,000 in state taxes, you could take a $30,000 deduction from your federal taxable income, thus reducing your federal income taxes by some fraction of $30,000 (depending on your tax bracket). The 2017 tax bill placed a $10,000 limit on this deduction. Some states responded by creating a provision where you could donate $30,000 to the state and receive a $30,000 credit against your state taxes owed \- so you end up paying the same amount to the state, but now you characterize it as a charitable donation, which is still deductible from your federal taxable income.

The new IRS regulation says that such a "donation" will no longer be deductible from your federal taxable income; that's all. Your state can still issue you a tax credit for such a donation if they want \- the federal government has no control over that \- but any such credit will reduce the amount you are allowed to deduct on your federal return, making the whole exercise pointless.

The federal government certainly has the power to determine how you should compute your income for the purposes of your federal income taxes, including what you may or may not deduct. That's the power they're using here.

45.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the provided information:

Question: The IRS recently nullified attempts by some states to bypass the $10,000 cap on state and local tax (SALT) deductions. Which of the following best describes the federal government's action and authority in this situation?

A) The federal government directly imposed new tax laws at the state level, prohibiting states from offering tax credits for charitable donations.

B) The IRS ruled that "donations" made in exchange for state tax credits would no longer be deductible on federal tax returns, effectively neutralizing state attempts to circumvent the SALT deduction cap.

C) The federal government banned states from establishing charitable funds that offer property tax credits in exchange for donations.

D) The IRS expanded its authority to determine how states can structure their tax systems, including what credits they can offer to taxpayers.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The IRS did not impose new tax laws at the state level or ban states from offering tax credits (eliminating options A and C). Instead, it used its authority to determine what can be deducted on federal tax returns. The IRS ruled that "donations" made to receive state tax credits would no longer be deductible on federal returns, thus neutralizing state attempts to bypass the SALT deduction cap. This action falls within the federal government's power to regulate federal income tax calculations, not an expansion of authority over state tax systems (eliminating option D). States can still offer such credits if they choose, but the federal tax benefit has been removed.

documentation.title: Annexation and becoming US president
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Imagine I was born in country X at xxxx.
At xxxx\+20 years country X is annexed to the United States. (Freely or forcefully)
At xxxx\+40 years I am elected to be the next president of the United States.

Can I legally be elected?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: At the time of annexation of country X someone would have to decide the status of the countries citizens: If all citizens of X are now citizens of the USA, and whether they are legally citizens from the date of annexation or since they were citizens of X, and if they are considered residents in the USA since the day they became residents of X, and if they are retrospectively "born in the USA" if they were born in X. And other things, like whether non\-citizen legal residents of X are now non\-citizen legal residents of the USA.

That has to be decided for many reasons, and the answer to your question follows naturally from this. Maybe you could check on a history site if anyone knows how this worked with Hawaii.

46.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: The country of Zephyria was annexed by the United States in 2030. John was born in Zephyria in 2000 and wants to run for U.S. President in 2060. Which of the following scenarios would most likely allow John to be legally elected as President?

A) The U.S. government declares all Zephyrian citizens to be U.S. citizens from the date of annexation, with no retroactive considerations.

B) The U.S. government grants Zephyrian-born individuals U.S. citizenship but doesn't consider them "natural born citizens" for constitutional purposes.

C) The U.S. government retroactively considers all Zephyrian territory as U.S. territory and all Zephyrian-born individuals as "natural born U.S. citizens" from their birth date.

D) The U.S. government allows Zephyrian citizens to apply for U.S. citizenship individually, with a 10-year waiting period.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C would most likely allow John to be legally elected as President. By retroactively considering Zephyria as U.S. territory and its citizens as "natural born U.S. citizens" from birth, John would meet the constitutional requirement of being a "natural born citizen" and at least 35 years old. Options A and B wouldn't satisfy the "natural born citizen" requirement, while option D wouldn't provide citizenship early enough for John to meet the 14-year U.S. residency requirement by 2060.

documentation.title: Will I get salary from the University for the served notice period?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I work with an Indian University. The notice period for resignation is three months as mentioned in the faculty handbook. Their rule also mentions,

"Faculty wishing to be released earlier than the notice period, for extraneous circumstances will be required to pay equivalent of salary and benefits for the notice period not served."

I resigned on 31st March and mentioned the three month notice period clearly in my resignation email. The dean then made the last working day, 30th April, since teaching for the semester ended that day. I did not worked for the university in May and June. Also it seems they changed the notice period forcibly to one month. Can they do so?

So should I be paid for May and June too? Shouldn't labour laws and hence the notice period be the same for both the employee and the employer?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, you should be paid for May \& June
---------------------------------------

By terminating you early, the university has chosen to reduce your notice period and must pay you out for the period you were contractually required to work.

How much you should be paid depends on how you are normally paid. For example:

* if you were a salaried employee paid the same amount every week/fortnight/month; then you should receive your normal salary.
* if you were a permanent part\-time or full\-time worker, then you should be paid your wage for your normal shifts.
* if you were a casual worker paid only for the shifts you are rostered onto, then the university owes you nothing because you wern't rostered on in May and June.

47.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Professor Singh resigned from his position at an Indian university on March 31st, giving the required three-month notice as per the faculty handbook. The dean, however, set his last working day as April 30th. The university did not require Professor Singh to work in May and June, nor did they pay him for these months. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this situation?

A) The university is not obligated to pay Professor Singh for May and June since he did not actually work during this period.

B) Professor Singh is entitled to full salary for May and June, regardless of the dean's decision to end his work duties early.

C) The university can unilaterally change the notice period from three months to one month without any consequences.

D) Professor Singh is only entitled to payment for May and June if he was a casual worker and had been scheduled for shifts during this period.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to labor laws and the principle that notice periods should be the same for both employee and employer, Professor Singh is entitled to full salary for May and June. By terminating his work duties early (on April 30th), the university effectively chose to reduce the notice period. However, they are still obligated to honor the original three-month notice period specified in the faculty handbook and Professor Singh's resignation letter. The university cannot unilaterally change the notice period without the employee's agreement. Since Professor Singh was presumably a salaried employee (as is common for university faculty), he should receive his normal salary for the full notice period, including May and June, even though he did not work during this time. This situation falls under the category where the employer chooses to release the employee earlier than the stipulated notice period, and thus must pay for the entire notice period as originally agreed upon.

documentation.title: Tenant Law - Pay full rent for one day over 30-day notice?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've been skimming over [this](https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displayText.xhtml?lawCode=CIV&division=3.&title=5.&part=4.&chapter=2.&article=) trying to find if a landlord can demand rent for me staying a day over my 30 day notice. Specifically because the landlord is out of town that day. Can a landlord demand full rent for me being one day over my 30 day notice because he is out of town to do a walk through? Seems illegal.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Assuming you have a lease of a year which expires on the 24th, you are supposed to surrender the premise by the end of that day. If you don't, then you are engaging in "unlawful detainer", and the landlord could go ahead with the legal process of booting you out. Supposing that in the meantime you do surrender the premise, then per §1952\.3, then it becomes an ordinary civil action. Either way, the landlord would be entitled to some relief (there is no law saying that you can stay an extra day). According to the [Department of Real Estate](http://www.dre.ca.gov/files/pdf/refbook/ref09.pdf) (p. 17\), the court can award owed\-rent damages to the landlord up to the date of the judgment. It's hard to say when that judgment would be handed down, because it depends on how busy the courts are, plus if the matter goes from (high\-priority) unlawful detainer to (low\-priority) regular civil procedure, that would extend the time to judgment and potentially the size of your liability. Typically, when you become a holdover tenant then you are in the "month\-to\-month" realm, so your rent obligation would extend for another month (by default, an agreement [is assumed](http://codes.findlaw.com/ca/civil-code/civ-sect-1944.html) to be for a month).

However: it's generally easy to get out of an apartment by the deadline and hand over the keys to the landlord or his agent. A "walk\-thorough" can be scheduled for the next Monday (for example), though you might want to take pictures before you go. There is actually [no legal requirement](http://www.dca.ca.gov/publications/landlordbook/sec-deposit.shtml) that the landlord allow you to be present for the post\-move\-out inspection, so in the worst case, you might have to get into a separate legal squabble over the security deposit, if you think he is making up damage.

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A tenant in California has given a 30-day notice to vacate their apartment, which expires on July 31st. The landlord is out of town on that day and cannot conduct a walk-through inspection. The tenant stays one extra day (August 1st) to wait for the landlord's return. What are the potential legal consequences for the tenant?

A) The tenant is not liable for any additional rent or penalties, as the landlord's absence excuses the extra day.
B) The tenant may be liable for a full month's rent, as they have become a holdover tenant on a month-to-month basis.
C) The tenant is only responsible for paying 1/30th of the monthly rent for the extra day stayed.
D) The landlord cannot pursue any legal action or damages against the tenant for the one-day overstay.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the documentation, when a tenant stays beyond their notice period, they become a holdover tenant. In California, holdover tenancies are typically treated as month-to-month agreements by default. This means the tenant may be liable for a full month's rent, even if they only stayed one extra day. The landlord's absence does not excuse the overstay, and there is no legal requirement for the landlord to be present for a walk-through inspection. The tenant should have vacated the premises by the end of their notice period and handed over the keys, regardless of the landlord's availability. Option B is correct because it accurately reflects the potential financial liability the tenant may face under California law for becoming a holdover tenant.

documentation.title: Is the New Jersey quarantine rule a legal requirement or merely a recommendation?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: According to the official [New Jersey COVID\-19 Information Hub](https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/travel-and-transportation/are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey) as of March 8, 2021 (emphasis in original),

> Travelers and residents returning from **any U.S. state or territory** beyond the immediate region (New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, and Delaware) should self\-quarantine at their home, hotel, or other temporary lodging following recommendations from the CDC:...

> The self\-quarantine is voluntary, but **compliance is expected**.

The site comes out and seems to say that the quarantine is voluntary, but then says that "compliance is expected".

Is there a *legal* penalty or intervention for not following the above guidelines, or are these rules enforced solely through social pressure (frowns, social ostracism, gossip, etc.)?

*To be clear*, I'm not asking for the *socially responsible* or *healthy* choice, but the *legal* one. For example, if someone were to walk into a NJ government office and loudly proclaim that they had just arrived from Texas and won't be self\-quarantining, is there anything they can do except appeal to the person's conscience? In other words, is the description of the quarantine as "voluntary" more a recognition that public health authorities are not actively monitoring and pursuing visitors as a matter of practice or is it a recognition that the state literally has no legal means to force visitors to comply?

*Also to be clear*, I'm asking solely about the general quarantine described above. Cases where someone has tested positive for COVID\-19 or been specifically identified as a close contact of someone who did are out of scope for this question.

*Why* someone would want to travel to New Jersey is out of scope for this question.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Is the New Jersey quarantine rule a legal requirement or merely a recommendation?

Even if the rule had force of law, the language indicates that self\-quarantine is optional. The term "expectation" merely indicates the government's preference.

[Black's Law Dictionary](http://heimatundrecht.de/sites/default/files/dokumente/Black%27sLaw4th.pdf) defines *voluntary* as "*unimpelled by another's influence \[...]. Proceeding from the free and unrestrained will of the person. \[...] Produced in or by an act of choice*". Likewise, *should* is defined as "*usually no more than an obligation of propriety or expediency, or a moral obligation, thereby distinguishing it from 'ought',*".

> is the description of the quarantine as "voluntary" more a recognition that public health authorities are not actively monitoring and pursuing visitors as a matter of practice or is it a recognition that the state literally has no legal means to force visitors to comply?

It suggests the former, although "monitoring" is different from "enforcing". The authorities could monitor merely for purposes of doing projections, that is, without penalizing the people who decide not to self\-quarantine.

The excerpt reflects that in the government's opinion the circumstances do not warrant making \[self\-]quarantine compulsory.

49.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to the New Jersey COVID-19 Information Hub, travelers returning from any U.S. state or territory beyond the immediate region should self-quarantine. The hub states that "compliance is expected" but also describes the quarantine as "voluntary." Based on this information and legal interpretation, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) The self-quarantine is legally mandated and non-compliance can result in legal penalties.

B) The self-quarantine is a strong recommendation but not legally enforceable.

C) The self-quarantine is only applicable to those who have tested positive for COVID-19.

D) The self-quarantine is mandatory only for visitors from specific high-risk states.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The language used in the New Jersey COVID-19 Information Hub suggests that while the government strongly recommends self-quarantine and expects compliance, it is not a legal requirement. The use of terms like "voluntary" and "should" indicates that it is a recommendation rather than a mandate. The phrase "compliance is expected" reflects the government's preference and desire for people to follow the guideline, but it does not imply legal enforceability. 

Answer A is incorrect because the quarantine is explicitly described as "voluntary," which means it cannot be legally mandated with penalties for non-compliance.

Answer C is incorrect because the question specifically states that cases where someone has tested positive for COVID-19 are out of scope for this particular guideline.

Answer D is incorrect because the guideline applies to travelers from "any U.S. state or territory" beyond the immediate region, not just specific high-risk states.

documentation.title: Copyright related issue on publishing a technical book?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am preparing to publish a technical book on programming that contains figures and charts (like, compiler, linker, ASCII table, keywords list) created by myself by taking references from many sources. Can I still need copyright clearance for using them in my book as the diagrams and charts are not originally designed by mine? Is the common conceptual figures like flowcharts of compilers, and list of programming keywords or ASCII table comes under copyright?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Putvi's answer is basically correct, but there are some points that should be further elaborated on. [This is a flow chart](https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Flowchart-Illustrating-The-BPSK-None-Return-to-Zero-NRZ-Converter-b-QPSK-Modulation_fig2_313243090) that reduces a concept to a standard notation. Use of boxes, ellipses, diamonds, lines etc. a conventional way to express certain ideas, and the shapes themselves are ancient so not protected. The same is true of many mathematical equations or structural formulae in chemistry. However, those ideas have often been instantiated in publications with the element of creativity required for copyright protection: a flowchart could be a piece of art (that is how graphic designers see their work product). Directly copying that artwork would be infringement of the artist's copyright. Since the ideas which the art expresses are unprotected, you can create your own art following standard conventions, and the result will look very similar to the protected artwork in a published book. That similarity is because there are very limited possibilities for variation, under those standards. A publisher may, however, insist that you get permission from an author, if they are not familiar with the presentation standards in your field (so you may have to argue with the publisher).

50.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An author is creating a technical programming book that includes flowcharts, diagrams, and tables (such as ASCII tables and keyword lists) inspired by various sources but recreated by the author. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding copyright considerations for these elements?

A) The author needs copyright clearance for all diagrams and charts, regardless of whether they were recreated or directly copied.

B) Flowcharts, ASCII tables, and keyword lists are always considered common knowledge and never require copyright clearance.

C) The author can use recreated diagrams and charts without copyright clearance, as long as they follow standard conventions and don't directly copy the artistic elements of the original sources.

D) Copyright clearance is only needed for flowcharts, but not for ASCII tables or keyword lists.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The key points from the documentation are:

1. Standard notations, conventions, and ideas (like the use of shapes in flowcharts or the content of ASCII tables) are not protected by copyright.

2. However, the specific artistic representation or implementation of these ideas in published works may be protected.

3. An author can create their own versions of these diagrams and charts following standard conventions without infringing on copyright, as long as they don't directly copy the artistic elements of existing publications.

4. The similarity between the author's creation and existing works would be due to the limited possibilities for variation under standard conventions, not because of copying.

5. While copyright clearance isn't legally required in this case, publishers might still insist on obtaining permission out of caution.

Option A is incorrect because clearance isn't needed for recreated diagrams that follow conventions. Option B oversimplifies the issue, ignoring potential artistic elements. Option D incorrectly singles out flowcharts and ignores potential copyright concerns for other elements.

documentation.title: Can a patient record interactions with their care providers under HIPAA?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: A friend of mine is currently in a hospital where the staff have told her (*verbally*) on multiple occasions that "her stay will be covered by her insurance". Yet, she received several thousand dollars in medical bills recently, from the institution itself and not her insurance company.

She has received some things in writing, but not as much about the financial process as she would have hoped (and nothing related to the bill she currently has). Thus, she is wondering if she can record her verbal interactions with hospital staff in order to hold them accountable if she is *told* that insurance will cover the costs, but she *still* receives a medical bill.

This could be seen as an invasion of privacy of the care provider(s); yet it pertains to her case and since they have sidestepped conversations about giving her the official financial paperwork, or written consent that what they say is actually true (they could be *saying* it's true just to get more money out of her), it seems that this would be legal to do.

As far as I understand it, HIPAA is meant to protect patients from care providers disclosing their medical information. Nothing I've read ([HIPAA Patient rights](http://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-individuals/guidance-materials-for-consumers/index.html); [HIPAA disclosures to family and friends](http://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/faq/disclosures-to-family-and-friends)) has anything about a patient's right to disclose their *own* information to whomever they want (in this case, family).

**Can she legally record her conversations with her care providers under HIPAA?** If so, what would be required on her part in order to ensure that said recordings would hold up in court if, in fact, staff were intentionally or unintentionally lying to her in order to bill her?

Yes I know it's highly unlikely that they would bother *not* billing insurance and try to screw her over. It's a long story, insurance claims have been difficult, just trying to figure out how to help her *not* rack up $10k\+ in medical bills due to unintentional or intentional fault on the side of the care providers.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is correct that HIPAA does not restrict what patients do. Recording a conversation may be governed by federal or state law: [this](http://www.dmlp.org/legal-guide/recording-phone-calls-and-conversations) is a good guide (check the relevant state law, in particular whether this is in a two\-party state). Insurance companies never bill patients, but they do send notices saying "here's what you must pay" (which should match what the hospital bills). Note that apart from the billing department (whom patients do not see), medical staff including check\-in receptionists do not and cannot know in real time what is actually covered for an individual, and they only give guesses. [This article](http://blogs.harvard.edu/billofhealth/2013/11/11/health-insurance-patient-responsibility-part-i/) and [the follow\-up](http://blogs.harvard.edu/billofhealth/2013/11/25/health-insurance-patient-responsibility-part-ii/) lightly discusses patient\-responsibility issues. It would be interesting, but expensive, to see whether suing a hospital for their staff being wrong about insurance can get you any relief.

51.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A patient is considering recording conversations with hospital staff regarding insurance coverage for her stay. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality and potential usefulness of such recordings?

A) HIPAA prohibits patients from recording conversations with healthcare providers without their consent.

B) Recordings made by the patient would be inadmissible in court due to privacy laws protecting healthcare workers.

C) The legality of recording conversations depends on state law, and the recordings could potentially be useful if the hospital staff provided incorrect information about coverage.

D) Medical staff, including receptionists, have real-time access to insurance coverage information, so their statements about coverage are always legally binding.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. HIPAA does not restrict patients from recording their own medical interactions. However, the legality of recording conversations without all parties' consent varies by state (one-party vs. two-party consent laws). If legal in the patient's state, such recordings could potentially be useful evidence if staff provided incorrect information about insurance coverage, although it's important to note that most medical staff cannot guarantee coverage in real-time. Options A and B are incorrect as HIPAA does not prohibit patients from recording, and such recordings could be admissible if obtained legally. Option D is incorrect because medical staff, especially non-billing personnel, typically cannot access real-time, definitive insurance coverage information for individual patients.

documentation.title: Indian father, Bangladeshi mother, a baby expect to be born in Ireland
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: This is my first post in this community.

I am an ordinary Indian passport holder, I am in Dublin, doing full\-time Ph.D. studies since October 2018 on a stamp 2 student visa. [http://www.inis.gov.ie/en/inis/pages/registration\-stamps](http://www.inis.gov.ie/en/inis/pages/registration-stamps)

My wife joined me in Dublin last year January, as an immediate dependent family\-member with me and she has given me a stamp 2A visa. She holds a Bangladeshi passport.

A baby is expected to be born in September in Dublin. What passport we should apply for, for the baby? Indian/Bangladeshi/Irish?

Thanks.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: * Your child probably does not qualify for Irish [birth citizenship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_nationality_law#Acquisition_of_citizenship) since residence of the parent on a student visa does not count.
* Your child probably does qualify for Indian citizenship since you are Indian and/or for Bangladeshi citizenship since the mother is Bangladeshi. Applying for both would make the child a dual citizen, which appears to be discouraged by Indian law.

Citizenship is such a serious matter that it might be a good idea to consult a lawyer. Before you do that, you could ask on Expatriates Stack Exchange so you know the right questions to ask.

52.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An Indian citizen and a Bangladeshi citizen are residing in Dublin, Ireland on student visas. They are expecting a child to be born in Dublin. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the citizenship options for their newborn child?

A) The child will automatically receive Irish citizenship due to being born in Ireland.
B) The child can only apply for either Indian or Bangladeshi citizenship, but not both.
C) The child is eligible for both Indian and Bangladeshi citizenship, but applying for both may be problematic under Indian law.
D) The child must wait until age 18 to choose between Indian, Bangladeshi, or Irish citizenship.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Based on the information provided, the child born in Dublin to Indian and Bangladeshi parents on student visas is not automatically eligible for Irish citizenship, as residence on a student visa does not count towards the requirements for birth citizenship in Ireland. However, the child is likely eligible for both Indian citizenship through the father and Bangladeshi citizenship through the mother. The correct answer notes that while the child is eligible for both, applying for dual citizenship may be discouraged by Indian law, making this option potentially problematic. Option A is incorrect because birth in Ireland does not automatically confer citizenship in this case. Option B is false because the child is eligible for both Indian and Bangladeshi citizenship. Option D is also incorrect, as the child does not need to wait until age 18 to obtain citizenship, nor would they automatically be eligible for Irish citizenship at that time based on the given information.

documentation.title: Divorce without the process of divorce; is it possible to obtain a dissolution after 15 years?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Suppose a couple eloped to Idaho in 2008\. They have not seen each other since 2009\. Suppose that one lives in Washington and then other lives in Colorado.

Is there a way for such a couple to get a dissolution of marriage without going through the divorce process?

Suppose further that there is one common child involved. Suppose further that he is 14 years old.

Suppose further that there was a no\-contact order in effect from 2009 to 2019 because of an assault by one member of the couple on the other, and the child.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The party who lives in Washington can petition dissolution under [this chapter](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=26.09&full=true). It does not matter where they were married or lived, what just matters that the party filing the petition lives in Washington. Having a child is not a bar to dissolution. That much is extremely simple. If the two parties cannot agree to the dissolution and to the child\-custody plan, lawyers would be involved to reach an agreement.

It is worth noting that for 50 years, divorce has been replaced in Washington with dissolution. It is also worth noting that there is an alternative path which may be more efficiency, namely legal separation. The primary downside of a separation is that it is a bar to re\-marriage (you are still married). But, under RCW 26\.09\.150

> No earlier than six months after entry of a decree of legal
> separation, on motion of either party, the court shall convert the
> decree of legal separation to a decree of dissolution of marriage or
> domestic partnership.

This is a matter of right that cannot be objected to.

53.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A couple who eloped to Idaho in 2008 and haven't seen each other since 2009 are seeking to end their marriage. One spouse lives in Washington, and the other in Colorado. They have a 14-year-old child together, and there was a no-contact order in effect from 2009 to 2019 due to assault. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding their options for ending the marriage in Washington state?

A) The couple must return to Idaho to file for divorce since that's where they were married.
B) They cannot file for dissolution in Washington because they have a minor child involved.
C) The spouse living in Washington can petition for dissolution, and after six months of legal separation, the court must convert it to a dissolution of marriage upon request.
D) The no-contact order prevents them from filing for dissolution in any state until it has been officially lifted by the court.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to Washington state law, the spouse living in Washington can petition for dissolution regardless of where the marriage took place. The presence of a child does not prevent dissolution. Additionally, the option of legal separation is available, which can be converted to a dissolution of marriage after six months upon the request of either party. This is a matter of right that cannot be objected to. The no-contact order being expired does not prevent them from filing for dissolution. Options A and B are incorrect as the location of marriage and presence of a child do not affect the ability to file in Washington. Option D is incorrect because the no-contact order is no longer in effect and wouldn't prevent filing even if it were.

documentation.title: Do I have authority to display images according to Terms of Use?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In my Android app submitting for approval I am using [OMDBApi.com](http://www.omdbapi.com) and showing movie posters were retrieving from their Api. According to [Terms of Use](http://www.omdbapi.com/legal.htm) do I have the authority to display content?

How can I provide to Google I do not violate any intellectual property?

google says:

I had to reject it because of an **unauthorized use of copyrighted content**.

Remove any content owned by a third party from your app. For exmaple; your app's store listing contains **official images of Thor in the Phone Screenshots** and Feature Graphics
Read through the [Unauthorized Use of Copyrighted Content](https://play.google.com/about/spam.html#impersonation-intellectual-property:unauthorized-use-of-copyrighted-content) article for more details and examples.
Make sure your app is compliant with the [Impersonation and Intellectual Property policy](https://play.google.com/about/spam.html#impersonation-intellectual-property) and all other policies listed in the Developer Program Policies. Remember that additional enforcement could occur if there are further policy issues with your apps.
Sign in to your Developer Console and submit your app.

This is how cover photo how app look like.

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/K48U4.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/K48U4.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Why do you think you haven't violated copyright?

As far as I can see, omdbapi.com says that their content is contributed by their users \- that means that they (probably) do not have the permission of the copyright holders and are violating copyright themselves.

If you buy something from a thief, you don't own it.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An app developer uses movie posters retrieved from OMDBApi.com in their Android app. Google rejects the app submission citing "unauthorized use of copyrighted content." Which of the following best explains why the developer's use of OMDBApi.com does not protect them from copyright infringement?

A) OMDBApi.com's Terms of Use explicitly prohibit the use of their content in mobile applications.

B) The developer failed to properly attribute the source of the movie posters in their app.

C) OMDBApi.com's content is user-contributed and likely lacks proper copyright permissions from original rights holders.

D) Google's policies automatically reject all apps that display any form of movie or TV show imagery.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because OMDBApi.com's content is user-contributed, which means the site itself likely doesn't have proper permissions from copyright holders. Using this content doesn't protect the app developer from copyright infringement, as illustrated by the principle that "if you buy something from a thief, you don't own it." Even if the API allows use of its data, it doesn't guarantee that the data is free from copyright restrictions. The app developer is still responsible for ensuring they have the right to use copyrighted content, regardless of where they obtained it.

documentation.title: How can you see if there is a criminal complaint against somebody in Germany?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: How can you see or know if there is a civil or criminal complaint against somebody in Germany? Is there a way to check this on Google?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Generally you can't, since a basic **Personality rights** exist for eveyone that must be balanced with public interest.

Allthough court proceedings are generally public, even the publication of when court sessions take place are very restrictive in the amount of information given out about what the session is about. How a court publishes this information seems to differ from court to court: public notice inside the court, press releases and sometimes an internet list.

Indictments, generally, may not be published before the proceedings begin ([§ 353d StGB](https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/englisch_stgb/englisch_stgb.html#p3298)).

### Proceedings before an Indictment

Since an Indictment will only be accepted by a court if the chances are that it more likely succeed than fail, you may assume that the police or state attorneys will be **even more restrictive** about publicizing any information about any *criminal complaint* (or investigation).

---

So the answer to your question, based on the reasons above is:

* no, there is no way to check this on google (from official sources)

---

**Sources**:

* [Öffentlichkeitsgrundsatz \- Wikipedia](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%96ffentlichkeitsgrundsatz) (German)
	+ [Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights \- Wikipedia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Article_6_of_the_European_Convention_on_Human_Rights#:%7E:text=Article%206%20reads%20as%20follows,impartial%20tribunal%20established%20by%20law.)
	+ [§ 169 \- Courts Constitution Act
	(Gerichtsverfassungsgesetz – GVG)](https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/englisch_gvg/englisch_gvg.html#p0808)
		- Publicity
		- [Justiz\-Ticker \- Berlin.de](https://www.berlin.de/gerichte/presse/justizticker/)
* [§ 353d StGB \- Unlawful disclosure concerning judicial hearings](https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/englisch_stgb/englisch_stgb.html#p3298)

55.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In Germany, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the public accessibility of information about civil or criminal complaints against individuals?

A) All court proceedings and complaints are freely available online for public access.
B) Information about complaints can be easily found through a Google search.
C) Court session details are widely published, but complaint information is restricted.
D) Access to information about complaints and proceedings is generally limited due to personality rights protections.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. In Germany, access to information about civil or criminal complaints and court proceedings is generally limited due to personality rights protections. The documentation emphasizes that there is a balance between personality rights and public interest. Court proceedings are generally public, but the information released about them is restrictive. Indictments cannot be published before proceedings begin, and law enforcement is even more restrictive about publicizing information on criminal complaints or investigations. The answer explicitly states that there is no way to check this information on Google from official sources. Options A and B are incorrect as they suggest easy accessibility, which contradicts the information provided. Option C is partially true about court sessions being public, but it incorrectly implies that this information is widely published, which is not the case according to the documentation.

documentation.title: How can the President appoint Whitaker as Acting Attorney General?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Today the president asked for and received the Attorney General’s resignation. Then it was announced that the DOJ Chief of Staff, Matthew Whitaker would be the Acting AG and according to the [Hill](https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/415591-acting-ag-to-take-over-oversight-of-russia-probe), NyPost, and others:

> "The Acting Attorney General is in charge of all matters under the purview of the Department of Justice," DOJ spokeswoman Sarah Isgur Flores said in a statement to The Hill.

And yet, on the basis of this legal analysis in [Slate](http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2017/07/if_donald_trump_fires_jeff_sessions_here_s_how_he_ll_appoint_a_successor.html) over a year ago, there are only three things that the President can do with respect to this without going through the Senate:

1. He could

> ... follow the terms of the DOJ succession statute and his own executive order on DOJ succession, under both of which the deputy attorney general, Rod Rosenstein, would automatically become the acting attorney general ...

2. The Federal Vacancies Reform Act of 1998:

> A more complicated scenario would be to rely on the provision codified at 5 U.S. Code Section 3345(a)(2\), which states: “notwithstanding \[the default rule that the deputy becomes the acting], the President (and only the President) may direct a person who serves in an office for which appointment is required to be made by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, to perform the functions and duties of the vacant office temporarily in an acting capacity...

3. An interim appointment of an actual AG.

To the best of my understanding none of these things have happened. He did not appoint the Deputy AG Rod Rosenstein, Whitaker as DOJ Chief of Staff has not gone through Senate approval, and he is not making an interim appointment. And yet I cannot find a single journalistic, legal, or even political source that has questioned the authority or the legality of the President's actions in this matter today.

Can someone who understands the legal issues here please explain to me what is going on (legally and/or constitutionally)?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Based on [5 U.S. Code Section 3345](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/5/3345), Matthew Whitaker appears to fulfill the criteria for subsection (a)(3\):

> notwithstanding paragraph (1\), the President (and only the President) may direct an officer or employee of such Executive agency to perform the functions and duties of the vacant office temporarily in an acting capacity, subject to the time limitations of section 3346, if—
> 
> 
> 
> > (A) during the 365\-day period preceding the date of death, resignation, or beginning of inability to serve of the applicable officer, the officer or employee served in a position in such agency for not less than 90 days; and
> > 
> > 
> > (B) the rate of pay for the position described under subparagraph (A) is equal to or greater than the minimum rate of pay payable for a position at GS–15 of the General Schedule.

He has held the Chief of Staff position for a little over a year, and the Chief of Staff position is almost certainly an [SES Pay Scale](https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/senior-executive-service/compensation/) position which would be higher than a GS\-15\. The time limitation in section 3346 mentioned only refers to the length of time he can serve as the acting attorney general.

It's worth noting that the next part is:

> (1\) Notwithstanding subsection (a)(1\), a person may not serve as an acting officer for an office under this section, if—
> 
> 
> 
> > (A) during the 365\-day period preceding the date of the death, resignation, or beginning of inability to serve, such person—
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > > (i) did not serve in the position of first assistant to the office of such officer; or
> > > 
> > > 
> > > (ii) served in the position of first assistant to the office of such officer for less than 90 days; and
> > 
> > 
> > (B) the President submits a nomination of such person to the Senate for appointment to such office.

As Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is the "first assistant" for the purpose of this section (see [28 U.S. Code Section 508](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/28/508)), this means that if the President decides to nominate Whitaker to the position, he would have to resign his acting position.

56.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Under what circumstances can Matthew Whitaker legally serve as Acting Attorney General without Senate confirmation?

A) If he has served in the Department of Justice for at least 90 days in the past year and his pay grade is at least GS-15
B) Only if he is nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate
C) If he has been Deputy Attorney General for at least 90 days
D) Only if Rod Rosenstein declines the position

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: According to 5 U.S. Code Section 3345(a)(3), the President may appoint an officer or employee of an Executive agency to serve as an acting official if they have served in the agency for at least 90 days in the past year and their pay rate is at least equal to GS-15. As DOJ Chief of Staff for over a year, Whitaker meets these criteria.

Option B is incorrect because the point of this provision is to allow temporary appointments without Senate confirmation.

Option C is incorrect because Whitaker was not Deputy Attorney General, and this refers to the automatic succession rule which wasn't used here.

Option D is incorrect because the President has the authority to choose Whitaker over Rosenstein using the Federal Vacancies Reform Act.

However, it's important to note that if Whitaker is nominated for the permanent position, he would need to step down as Acting AG during the confirmation process.

documentation.title: What is the minimum time an employer must give before cancelling work?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I do sporadic work for a company. I had a shift scheduled for over a month. I messaged my manager the day before asking if there's anything else I needed to know. She told me the shift was cancelled. She said because it was more than 24 hours they didn't have to pay me anything.

Is there some law about not getting paid if warned 24 hours in advanced? Do I have a case worth pursuing or not really? I'm located in BC however the office is in Ontario. None of the paper work I signed said anything about how the company can cancel on me.

The company wants to think I'm a contractor, however I know it's not up to what the contract says if it's an employee relationship or contractor. Is this what the decision would come down to? Can regular employees have shifts cancelled with 24 hours notice? Notwithstanding the contract, [I believe I would be considered an employee](https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/forms-publications/publications/rc4110/employee-self-employed.html#factors).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: For both [BC](https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/employment-business/employment-standards-advice/employment-standards/hours) and [Ontario](https://www.labourandemploymentlaw.com/2018/11/ontarios-bill-47-gets-green-light/), so long as the shift is cancelled before you report to work, you aren't entitled to any pay. (Ontario was to implement 48 hours notice as of January 1 this year, but there was a change in government and that got repealed.)

If you work in a [federally regulated industry](https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/programs/employment-equity/regulated-industries.html) and thus fall under the *Canada Labour Code*, the situation appears to be the same. However, as of September 1, 24 hours notice [will be required](https://hicksmorley.com/2019/06/13/significant-canada-labour-code-reforms-to-come-into-force-september-1-2019/).

57.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An employee in British Columbia has sporadic shifts scheduled with a company based in Ontario. The company cancels a shift with 25 hours notice. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the employee's right to compensation?

A) The employee is entitled to full pay for the cancelled shift, as BC labor laws require 48 hours notice for cancellation.

B) The employee is entitled to partial pay (3 hours minimum) for the cancelled shift, as Ontario labor laws apply in this case.

C) The employee is not entitled to any pay for the cancelled shift, as both BC and Ontario laws allow shift cancellation without compensation if done before the employee reports to work.

D) The employee's right to compensation depends on whether they are classified as an employee or contractor, regardless of the notice period given.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the information provided, both British Columbia and Ontario labor laws allow employers to cancel shifts without compensation as long as the cancellation occurs before the employee reports to work. The location of the employee (BC) and the company office (Ontario) does not change this fact. The 24-hour notice mentioned by the manager is not a legal requirement for avoiding payment in either province. The employee's classification as a contractor or employee, while important for other aspects of the working relationship, does not affect the rules regarding shift cancellation in this scenario.

documentation.title: What is the proper way of handling non-USPS packages for long-gone tenants?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I moved into a rental home around 2 years ago immediately on the heels of a previous tenant. I experienced the usual "mail overlap" period of a few weeks, during which I was happy to pass letters \& small packages either back to our carrier. These trickled away and I felt like things had settled. 

Then, the first "big box" came. 

It seems the previous tenant works in sales/marketing, and about once a month I've gotten large packages from various marketing firms. Most of these are shipped via non\-USPS carriers (UPS \& FedEx are most prevalent here, though I've occasionally seen DHL as well). Initially, I tried taking these to our property managers, but they informed me that they had no forwarding info for the previous tenants and that I should follow up with the delivery folks instead. Our landlord was similarly stumped regarding getting in touch with the former tenants. I spoke to a couple drivers and was told that they could take them, but that they would likely be redelivered. I tried this and had the packages redelivered multiple times by different drivers before giving up.
